captions.text: START

00:01
AIMEE: I'm achieving things, and I want other

anorexics to see that they can achieve things
as well because it's such a trait with the

illness that you don't have any belief
in yourself.

00:12
COMM: Like so many teenagers Aimee Corner
was desperate to fit in.

00:17
AIMEE: I used to look at all the popular girls

and they used to be like quite thin and I
thought if I'm thin then maybe people will
start liking me.

00:26
COMM: And this belief led her to starve herself
until she was dangerously underweight.

00:31
AIMEE: I always wanted to get down to four

and a half stone, and that was like my goal
weight. I think realistically I knew I would

never get to it because I probably would have
died.

00:43
COMM: Aimee, from Washington, Tyne and Wear

admits she was just eight years old when her
problems with foods began.

00:49
AIMEE: I just remember like as tory being

told by my dad and it was about someone who
knew that his friend had choked on a piece

of meat and I thought I better stop eating
my food fast and it got to the stage where
I was frightened to eat any solid foods,

01:10
COMM: And by the age of 14, her difficulties

had escalated as she faced bullying, and
desperately wanted to be liked at school.

01:17
AIMEE: I thought people would start to like

me more if I lost weight because I thought
I would change into a different person. I

just thought I'll just keep losing weight,
I don't care, I just don't care about eating
any more and I got down to literally thinking I could survive off like a spoonful of
yoghurt and two forkfuls of potato.

01:35
MAUREEN: We knew she was losing weight

but we didn't think it was that. We didn't
realise it was anorexia.

01:41
COMM: As well as starving herself Aimee was

also exercising compulsively to increase her
weight loss.

01:48
AIMEE: As I got more and more unwell, like

I couldn't like do proper exercise, so I used
to walk everywhere but then it gradually built

up, I mean some mornings I wasn't even going
to sixth form because I would spend the entire
morning walking around like, the local area.

02:03
AIMEE: Then I would walk to sixth form for

like two hours in the afternoon, then I would
walk home, and then I would try and get out

again to walk even more. At most I would say
I was doing like 6 to 8 hours of walking a
day.

02:16
COMM: Eventually her obsession saw her stop
eating and drinking for two whole weeks.

02:21
AIMEE: I thought if I didn't eat at all then

my weight loss would continue rapidly and
I thought I'm sorted.

02:27
AIMEE: But then obviously they caught me in
time to put me in the hospital.

02:31
COMM: Being hospitalised was the wake up call
she needed.

02:34
AIMEE: I remember sitting in the ambulance

on the way to the hospital and the paramedic
was like I don't actually know how you're

still conscious or how you're actually still
alive because someone with a blood sugar this
low should be a coma, they should be dead.

02:48
AIMEE: It's horrible when I look, I don't

look like me, I look like an old woman. Like
it just ages you so much, I look like seventy

on some of them photos and I used to think
I looked nice.

03:01
DIANE: I was in hospital with her and obviously

I had to wash her and I know it sounds awful
but can't - I couldn't bear to like touch

her, when you washed her you could
feel everything, like her shoulder, collar

bones, her spine and her hair was coming out
in clumps, it just broke my heart.

03:23
COMM: Now nineteen, Aimee is trying to increase
her weight to a healthy eight stone, two.

03:29
AIMEE: But it wasn't until I hit my lowest

weight and then something clicked in my head
and I actually can't live like this. I thought

I've had like five years of this, I just can't
deal with it any longer so I started eating

and eventually I put on like a bit of weight
and they discharged me, I'm eating better

than I've ever ate in about five years, COMM: And
she's about to start a degree in Psychology.

03:54
AIMEE: I want to be able to help other anorexics

because it makes me feel awful seeing how
much they suffer and I've conquered some

of my fears and I want to show them from a
recovered anorexic's point of view that you
can do it.

title: Teen Anorexia Survivor Wants To Help Others Battle Eating Disorders

vegetarian.﻿

comments.text:
Her story is inspiring, but until she gets to a minimally healthy weight,

comments.author: spinningincirclezzz

comments.text:
+spinningincirclezzz Anorexia is a mental illness. Recovery is not just 
physical, it's mental. Just like an addict, or a person with any other 
mental illness, you're never fully recovered. You're always in recovery. 
Recovering from anorexia is very difficult because not only have you 
mentally changed your body has also changed. The biochemical structure of 
your brain has changed, your body does not have hunger cues (does not tell 
you when you're hungry or not hungry anymore), and so recovering from 
anorexia takes reprogramming both mentally and physically. Also, you can't 
put on weight too quickly, it's dangerous after starving for so long. Her 
path to a healthy weight will take time. She might also always look thin, 
but as long as she is within range of healthy weight that's all that maters.

comments.author: Lily Aldridge

comments.text:
I was in a home where we didn't have enough to eat, and as a result I was 
so thin at age 11 that my ribs showed, and kids used to make fun of me for 
being a human walking stick. A few months before I turned 12, I was moved 
up North, and I practically pigged out of food since there was so much of 
it in my new home. As a result I got really chubby to the point of having a 
big pot belly, and kids there (who were going through the "Thin is Utmost 
Beauty" trend) would bully me relentlessly for being a fat pig. I then had 
an appendix operation when I was thirteen and I lost a lot of pounds 
because of it, seeing as it hurt too much to even breathe let alone eat. At 
fourteen, I gained back some of the weight I lost and have a muffin top 
(nothing too bad, average) and the girls at my school were BONE THIN (or 
attempting to) and it just horrified me. Who would want to be this thin in 
the first place?? Why starve in order to reach the Photoshopped standards 
in magazines? Then came along age 14, when I was in my last year of middle 
school. Thin was the new beauty, and compared to the other 14 year olds, I 
looked overweight by comparison. My Old school offered no help for eating 
disorders, and wherever I went I became severely self conscious of how I 
looked, and during the wintyr break I had started cutting back and tried 
eating salad, tons of it because I knew that if you ate too little your 
body just clung onto the fat longer. I admit, I have a chubby baby face, 
and when I hold my head straight and tall, the extra baby fat pushed back 
and made me look like I had a double chin, so I started slouching, keeping 
my head low and if I had to look up, I'd tilt it like a puppy, that way the 
fat wasn't s noticeably. The problem with this was that my head is 
permanently fixated like this, for when I rightened up my head I felt off 
balance and dizzy. Now I am at my old school, where everyone is average 
sized or a chunky, and I feel almost completely better, There is always one 
reminder though, of my previous life when there wasn't enough food-my 
wrists are near-bone thin, and I am ashamed of them. Back then, I didn't 
choose to be skinny, and I was stuck with these wrists that belonged to a 
eight year old while having hands that looked ginormous because of it.﻿

I was anorexic at 11
And 12 because of verbal sexual abuse and to this day (I'm almost 15) I 
still fight and struggle. At 13 I gained a shit load of weight and now I'm 
trying to lose it. My highest weight was 200 lbs at 5'2! (I carry my weight 
very well. My dads side of the family is very curvy, chubby or not, they 
have natural curves) right now 2 months into my weight loss I weight 185!! 
I'm so happy but day to day I struggle with thinking if I eat I'll just get 
fatter. And that if I skip a meal I'll get thinner. It's terrible!! ﻿

comments.text:
I hate my body so much. I've always been overweight and at one point I was 
close to obesity. Now I'm trying to lose weight but I'm scared of the scale 
so the last time I checked (Ealry this month) I weighed 133. I'm 5 5". 
People say I'm fine but I have a stomach from all those years of being fat. 
My limbs have Extra fat on them, my head is huge, and I have no butt or 
boobs. I had some friends over last night and I ate: ice cream, 1 slice of 
pizza, 3 cups of soda, 2 kisses, 3 brownies, 1 bag of chips, etc. and for 
breakfast I had cake and 1/4 of a pancake and coffee and yogurt with mnm's. 
And my mom made white Alfredo pasta and forced me to eat it! And my bday is 
on Monday so I'll wanna eat unhealthy. Ik I'm gonna weight so I feel so 
guilty and I just wish I was skinny. My solution is to eat 1 meal 
Tuesday-Friday and to be active bc I don't have time to excersize. I feel 
so guilty, and my depression, anxiety, and being suicidal doesn't help.﻿
comments.author: Ariana Oyola

comments.text:
+Marta D The problem with meat isn't only in its acidity but the way it is 
prepared and other cancerogenic substances that are created in the 
process.. And also in the way the animals are treated and 'cured' during 
their breeding. I do not agree that there is only one diet that suits all 
people because some conditions don't permit it, but there are definitely 
many good points about plant based diet. As a nutritionist I can't be 
biased and must be able to accept other's beliefs (if it's not endangering 
their health) so sometimes I have to work around that. I will probably pick 
up the book when I'm not so busy so thanks for recommendation :)
comments.author: medea.

comments.text:
+medea. which means it's healthiest to eat alkaline foods. Meat for example 
creates an acidic environment in the body, in which diseases survive. 
people who are raw vegan or fruitarian don't suffer from any diseases 
unless it's in the detox state (or if they don't eat properly, but that 
goes for any eating habit). that should tell you something... 
As I said, Dr Morse has 40 years experience in healing/curing 95% of his 
patients with a fruit/plant based diet. look him up, his book is called The 
Detox Miracle Sourcebook and he's on youtube as well, Robert Morse N.D

The only reason I'm saying this is to help you and anyone who is reading 
because I want people to be healthy and happy.
comments.author: Marta D

comments.text:
+Marta D Yes, human body has a pH of 7.35 - 7.45 any more or less than that 
and you die. It is >slightly< alkaline, but never acidic. I am not sure 
what that has to do with anything, acidification of the body is a myth. 
Other than that.. yes, I know, I have listened to years of lectures about 
nutrition and diets. Speaking about taking things into consideration and 
slightly off topic, did you know that ketogenic diet helps some people with 
their epileptic seizures? >Sometimes< heath conditions or any other slight 
differences do make big changes (such, as mentioned before, lactose 
in/tolerance). And yes there is also something called fructose 
malabsorption.
comments.author: medea.

comments.text:
+medea. but you have to understand detoxification before you completely 
dismiss a diet because you had a bad reaction to it. most people will have 
a ''bad reaction'' to raw vegan food because they will detox, which is 
good. sure our die is individual but humans are one species meaning we are 
all designed for a certain diet. it's not like some humans are designed for 
meat diets and some arent. you have to take so much more into consideration 
when you analyze a person's diet and what will benefit them, such as what 
their parents ate before during pregnancy and during breastfeeding, what 
the person was fed growing up etc etc.... 

one thing to remember is that the human body is designed to be alkaline.
comments.author: Marta D

comments.text:
+Marta D I did not say anything about accuracy, just stated my opinion and 
standing because there are so many info about 'eating the right way' from 
eating everything (from meat to plants that many people swear by and might 
not be the healthiest) to eating 75% proteins or 75% fat and so on. 
Mentioning my degree was just so no one could say I'm just someone spewing 
shit :) There are many opinions on what is healthy and many diets that 
treat different conditions, so I fully agree with your statement that she 
should listen to her body in the first place. Every body reacts in a 
different way. A diet is a very individual thing. However I had a case when 
a patient had bad reactions to raw fruit and vegetables and in cases like 
that you have to compensate, so advocating fruit/plant based diet in 
everyway might not be the best thing. But definitely healthier than most.
comments.author: medea.

comments.text:
+medea. your degree in nutrition doesn't give you more accuracy. Dr Morse 
with 40 years of experience in treating ill people with a plant based/fruit 
based diet, however, has accuracy
comments.author: Marta D

comments.text:
+Marta D As someone who has a degree in nutrition I do not agree and would 
never suggest soy milk. Also I have not seen one person getting fat form 
milk, but then again there aren't many fat people here. The main problem 
with milk is lactose intolerance which many people have. But I do agree 
that it matters what the calories consist of. And I also find it funny how 
you call some of your food garbage but then a few words after 'much 
healthier because it's vegan' :D If you prepare it the healthy way it is 
not garbage now, is it? :P
comments.author: medea.

comments.text: +Cerita Spady GIRL did you just read my wall of text above?? If not, do it
comments.author: Marta D

comments.text: I wish I weighed 133 😒😒
comments.author: Cerita Spady

comments.text:
You shouldn't be concerned with the numbers on the scale. muscles weigh 
more than fat and so on so you really can't know what it is that is 
weighing. Just like you can't know if 100 kcal is good or bad, because what 
matters is what the calories consist of. 
For example, 100 kcal of cow milk is much more unhealthy than 100 kcal of 
soy milk. 100 kcal or beef is much more unhealthy than 100 kcal of soy 
beans. 
My suggestion is that you make eating a happy and joyful action rather than 
a guilty one. See food as FUEL, because that's what it is. The food fuels 
your body so it's best to eat food that suits your body so that you feel on 
top. 

I eat a lot of garbage, chips, pancakes almost every day with whipped soy 
cream etc. But it's all vegan, so it's much much healthier. Milk from 
animals is made for the baby to GROW, that's why people gain so much weight 
from it. milk is for babies. 

Your stomach can tell you when you should stop eating in two ways: either 
it has expanded so much that it knows you have had enough food, OR it has 
been filled with enough calories/''nutrition'' so that it tells you it 
doesn't need any more. you could have a half empty stomach with oils and 
other unhealthy things, or you can have a full stomach with spinach and 
fruit which will make you so happy and energetic.

I'm not saying you should focus on losing weight, I'm saying you should 
focus on what makes you feel the best physically, mentally and emotionally. 
I realized this is a lot of text so if you're interested you can please 
send me a message or we can just talk in the comments. good luck and happy 
birthday :)
comments.author: Marta D
